Pre-Game Insights: Germany have averaged 3.5 goals per game in the Nations League so far, creating an average of six big chances per match, highlighting their efficiency in front of goal.
Bosnia’s Leaky Defence: Bosnia-Herzegovina have conceded an average of 2.5 goals per game in the Nations League, including a 5-2 hammering by the Netherlands, showcasing their defensive frailties.
Germany’s Dominance: Germany have scored at least twice in six of their last eight matches, making them a dangerous proposition for any defence, particularly one as vulnerable as Bosnia’s.
Germany’s tendency to hit the ground running in such matches also makes them likely to push for early goals.
Bosnia’s inability to threaten top-tier opposition suggests they will struggle to breach Germany’s defence.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Bosnia’s recent home form in the Nations League shows they can be competitive, their overall run of seven defeats in eight games tells a different story.
Germany’s attacking lineup is expected to continue their dominant form.
Florian Wirtz, who has been instrumental in Germany’s attacking plays, could easily set the tempo and supply chances for the likes of Deniz Undav and Jonathan Burkardt.
